Problem:
Let's consider the probability density function \( p(z) \) that describes the distribution of a random variable \( Z \) undergoing the Fourier Transform \( \hat{p}(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty p(z)e^{-i\omega z} dz \). We investigate how transformations in the time domain and frequency domain affect this PDF.

Given \( \hat{q}(\omega) = e^{-i\omega a}\hat{p}(\omega) \), can we deduce the value of \( a \) properly without knowing the form of \( p(z) \)?
Explanation: Identifying the value of \( a \) uniquely from \( \hat{q}(\omega) \) requires knowledge about the baseline function \( \hat{p}(\omega) \). Without knowing \( p(z) \), multiple values of \( a \) could theoretically correspond to the observed changes in \( \hat{q}(\omega) \), precluding accurate back-calculation of \( a \).
